question: Nothing yet. Wait a minute -- there's Hal. And his date.
answer: How do they look?

question: He's signalling "okay."
answer: Where's Gabe?

question: Excuse me -- I know you're my salvation, and all -- do you think you could rescue us before your smoke break?
answer: Maybe you could tell me why I am rescuing you.

question: Basically -- I've fallen down, and I can't get up...
answer: Rescue One -- have located helpless climber, please prepare idiot line for transport, over -- who precariously swings out from the ledge to grab it -- the wire is just out of reach. Hal grabs the radio.

question: Ready? Did he tell you about the time he almost made it up Everest?
answer: He said you gave him a bad oxygen mask

question: Well, if he's bored you with that bullshit, then this has to be the best part of a bad date. Right? Ready?
answer: Okay -- I can't --

question: Yes you can. You can do it. Don't look down. The whole way across, don't look down. Look at me. Just keep looking at me -- and you'll be okay. Sure?
answer: Yeah. I have always depended on the kindness of Rangers.

question: too scared to breathe, dangles on the remaining strand of what used to be the harness -- she sways from the wind and the jerk of her own weight, her grip loosens --
answer: moves back from the ledge. Hold on. I'm coming out to get you.

question: is in trouble -- the bobbing of the line from Gabe's weight and the winds are making her lose her grip even more --
answer: urgently pulls himself along the line faster, trying not to shake the line. As he gets closer and closer to a terrified Susan, his eyes lock on hers -- Keep looking at me. Hold on --

question: who stares at Gabe, petrified -- this focus is helping, but her strength is just about gone -- falls --
answer: deliberately lets go of the main line and launches himself at Susan -- who can only look down, swaying helplessly on the wire as Susan's SCREAM starts -- twists from his safety line, spinning helplessly -- he wants to, but can't, shut his eyes -- Falling. Any size, any color, any model. Just under six hours.

question: deliberately lets go of the main line and launches himself at Susan -- who can only look down, swaying helplessly on the wire as Susan's SCREAM starts -- twists from his safety line, spinning helplessly -- he wants to, but can't, shut his eyes -- Falling. Any size, any color, any model. Just under six hours.
answer: You aren't wasting any time, are you? who is standing off to the side. I knew you'd be coming by. Today. If you're in that much of a hurry, why don't you ride with me?

question: This is new...
answer: It's a thermal scope -- picks up body heat of lost hikers --

question: Still find the dead ones the old fashioned way, I guess.
answer: You could have said goodbye.

question: If I did, I'd have to listen to you tell me one more time that it wasn't my fault.
answer: Today -- especially today -- you get to hear it again. The harness clip broke. Cold stress -- one in a million equipment failure. You and Hal could have checked it from then till now and it still would have happened. You did everything right --

question: I'm not sure what I wish more, Maggie. That you meant what you said, just now -- or that it were really true then.
answer: Maggie, where the hell have you been? I've got two climbers out -- Brett and Evan are up there again to jump off the spur. Their wives called twice. I want you in the air and I want them found before the storm system moves in. Now.

question: Christ. You're in charge of Rescue now?
answer: There was a vacancy. Maybe you heard about it. The last guy lost his nerve and lit out of town.

question: We got word that somebody's been observing your currency shipments -- this load, the $5,000s -- over the last three deliveries.
answer: There isn't a hell of a lot anyone can do but observe. This is the most protected shipment we've got -- and the most useless for a thief. Those bills aren't in circulation. You think five thousand dollar bills are easy to pass? Who the fuck would try?

question: This guy might.
answer: Who is he? Could you get to the part where I'm supposed to care?

question: We had two agents monitoring him. These two -- Gleason and Quinones. Their last report said he was going to try to take this shipment.
answer: Thanks for the tip. But I've got work to do.

question: Did I say "last" report? I think I did. I mean last fucking report. These guys have vanished.
answer: You have my sympathy, but -- There's a reason we do things this way, all right? Armored cars can be hijacked. Trains can be derailed. But nobody can get to us in flight. The only time this is on the ground is at the mint, or on the Presidio runway in San Francisco. Either way, someone would have to shoot his way past a couple of thousand guards. If you're worried about an inside job, forget it. I checked the plane from top to bottom an hour ago. And these three are my best against. Even if one of them did go skydiving, they wouldn't get far. Each case has an electronic tracer with a range of one hundred miles. I haven't lost a bill in eight years. And I'm not scrubbing this shipment because you scare easily.

question: Rescue One to base, over.
answer: Rescue One -- have you sighted them? Over --

question: Negative, Hal -- storm's already moving in -- I can't see them, and winds are too strong to stay up here -- over --
answer: Rescue One -- abort. They'll be all right. Brett and Evan are dumb enough not to log in, but they're smart enough to have storm gear. Head back to base. Maybe you can catch Gabe before he leaves. Over.

question: Stay put! Don't panic, goddammit! No -- we're going too fast, and we're too high up. Push flaps forward twenty degrees and drop to five thousand feet.
answer: You got any rifles? backs up in horror -- and he sees Travers calmly coming out of the cockpit. Rattled, Matheson pulls his gun on Travers. Travers looks dumbfounded -- then angry.

question: What the hell are you doing --
answer: Checked the plane from top to bottom, huh? You fucker -- Put your hands behind your head! It's over!

question: Calm down -- give the gun to me --
answer: There's a couple of dead bodies in the front compartment -- they're FBI agents --

question: He's losing it --
answer: Goddamn it! Don't you see what he's doing! He's hijacking the fucking shipment! Don't make me shoot you!

question: So what. He'll sift though a plane that went down in a storm -- -- find enough pulverized bone for six men heroically killed in the line of duty -- -- and just enough of the right kind of ash. We get twenty-one gun funerals and they write off fifty million. It's perfect, as long as you hold the plane steady -- so concentrate.
answer: Travers -- hurry it up.

question: On my way. That charge is going to blow both engines -- the plane'll go down like a rock, so clip yourself on to the end of the cable with the money as soon as I get over. And make sure you bring the right cases. Dip the plane. I'm coming over.
answer: Why didn't you send the money over?

question: Mayday -- mayday -- downed DC-3 -- mayday --
answer: Rocky Mountain Rescue -- come in, mayday --

question: Downed charter flight alpha-charlie-niner-- -- dead, seven seriously wounded, acknowledge --
answer: Acknowledged, mayday. What's your position?

question: Don't know -- position unknown -- landed on top of some mountain -- only visual bearing is a facing cylinder-type formation -- over --
answer: Got to be Comb Bluff. Acknowledged, mayday. Winds are too strong for us to get a copter up there -- can you and your passengers make it through the storm? Over -- Mayday -- come in, mayday --

question: pulls into the driveway and puts the Bronco in park. He doesn't cut the engine, because he's not sure whether he's going in or not. Finally -- he cuts the ignition. Maggie?
answer: Hey there --

question: Hi. Could you introduce us?
answer: Sure. Gabe Walker -- this is A27. A27 -- Gabe.

question: Not the tag -- what do you call him?
answer: Her. I call her Lucky.

question: Poachers? Bastards...
answer: They got the mother -- and left this one behind. Too small to make a decent trophy, I guess.

question: About four months, right? Christ -- it must have been just about his -- I mean her -- first flight --
answer: Time to change the dressing.

question: You can't do that alone --
answer: I've had to learn. She trust me --

question: I'm making her nervous -- You hold her, I'll do the dressing. Got some fight in her -- that's good. What happened to Dave?
answer: The usual. Flew off -- never calls, never writes -- I'm glad to see you, Gabe. But I kind of wish you hadn't come. I was almost used to you being gone. Why are you here?

question: I thought I came back to see if I'd learned to live with it. Well, big surprise. Coming back just tore me open all over again, like it all happened yesterday instead of a year ago. Nothing's changed. Including the way I feel about you. I didn't realize it till I saw you at the airport. But I came back for you, Maggie.
answer: Does that mean you're going to stay?

question: No. Not here. I want you come with me. Start over, somewhere else.
answer: You come back after being gone a year, and you expect me to -- You don't live here any more, Gabe. Your choice, remember? But this is my home. I'm not leaving. You can stay with me, or you can go alone. It's still your choice.

question: Now there's an easy call.
answer: What the hell do you want?

question: I need your help. A plane's gone down on Comb Bluff. This storm would blow a copter all over the place -- but we can climb up to it.
answer: "We"? Talk to somebody who's still on the payroll. You've got a half dozen new guys --

question: -- who couldn't climb that wall now if there were stairs cut into it. But you've soloed it.
answer: During the summer. On a bet.

question: This is a little more important than a bet. Just a few injured people with no first aid or shelter, camping in a zero degree blizzard. They'll be ice sculptures by tomorrow morning.
answer: Maybe you missed the headlines -- but I don't do rescues any more. They're bad for my conscience. Fuck this one up on your own.

question: Play it again, Gabe, about how we killed her. I was there too, remember?
answer: Not like I was, pal -- her fingers brushed mine on the way down --

question: -- and I was the one who had to deal with her family when you fucking tore out of town. We lost her. Whatever anybody says about cold stress and the clip, you and I have to live with that. But right now, there are some more people who need our help, and they shouldn't die too just because you've got a problem keeping the past in the past.
answer: I don't want the responsibility.

question: Walk away and you are responsible. They'll die. I can't do this alone. You know what else, Gabe? You can go anywhere you want, but if you don't do this, now, you're going to be stuck on that goddamn ledge for the rest of your life. That thing's dead weight. Completely useless for an ice climb.
answer: Just backup. I'll lead. I left a few bolts last time I climbed this -- I think I can find some of them.

question: Save the rope for when it gets tough. That bet was for you to free climb the wall.
answer: Tell you what, Hal -- if we're still alive tomorrow morning, I'll give you the twenty bucks back, okay? Anchored!

question: is beside and slightly below Gabe -- at the other end of the fifty foot rope. Hal cautiously pulls himself along the line to the first piton -- as is standard for a climb, he pulls out the piton, then moves on to the second -- but up above
answer: hugs the ice wall, making himself as flat as possible -- Rockslide!

question: flattens too as rocks bounce past -- the second anchoring piton LOOSENS as it is struck by a falling rock -- Hal nervously eyes the last piton between him and Gabe -- tries to stay flat, but one boulder painfully CLIPS him on the shoulder, knocking him from his perch -- Hal falls --
answer: who's seen everything we have, quickly reaches to the piton he's just anchored, and removes the carabiner clip -- has the bolt gun out. He rapidly hooks the rope's carabiner clip to the chambered bolt, and FIRES it at a solid rock ledge above him -- lashes the rope to his shoulder, bracing for the coming impact by lodging his feet in the ice -- is almost dragged down by the jolt -- he painfully takes most of the impact in his shoulders -- the shock forces his feet through an ice ledge -- but the rope, bolted to the rock above, has held. Barely. Anchored -- Anchored!

question: now somewhat recovered, steadies himself. You're sure this time -- Don't say it --
answer: It's kind of hard to resist --

question: Come on -- the hard part's over.
answer: That's it.

question: I thought the fuselage was broken. That looks pretty cozy.
answer: The pilot was hysterical.

question: Something's wrong here --
answer: Does this look like a prank to you? Come on -- Relax -- we're here to help -- Don't try to talk --

question: This way. We don't have to do this. We know these mountains -- they don't. If we can get ahead --
answer: Can you climb faster than they can shoot?

question: We've got to try something. Think we'll get a finder's fee after they get all their "luggage"?
answer: Sure. All the bullets we can eat.

question: That's not what really worries me.
answer: There's something else to worry about?

question: Yeah. Once they've got what they're after -- they're gonna need a copter to get out of here.
answer: Maggie.

question: You win. Kill him when he gets down.
answer: Jesus.

question: Lower it down -- now!
answer: I've got a better idea. Why don't you come up and get it?

question: Get him!
answer: who has to flatten against the upper ledge -- bullets howl past at twenty per second, SPARKING against the lip of the rock -- it's cover, but not much --

question: Forget it -- downdrafts would wipe her all over the peaks -- -- Not that I expect you to give a shit, but it's our only copter. You'll be stuck.
answer: I can handle the winds --

question: Forget about it, Maggie, that's an order -- acknowledge --
answer: Acknowledged. Let me talk to Gabe -- over --

question: You can't. He's taking care of passengers. Just like I should be. Over and out.
answer: Good. You might live longer than your friend. Now -- -- what?

question: The next one's on top of the peak. This'll be long, but easy -- more like a hike than a climb.
answer: It looks like a winding route.

question: Okay -- I know it's not in San Francisco. I know it's not here. I know it's not in any fucking airport from here to Montana. Where it's not - we got that covered. Now, do you have any ideas on where it is?
answer: There's no radio contact, sir. At all. We're not receiving the tracer signal from the cockpit's flight recorder. Radar lost it after it went low here. We have to assume it went down in the storm.

question: Air search?
answer: That storm hasn't quit yet. Weather service says we've got it until tomorrow morning at least. Even if we could get a plane up now, it'd be impossible to see anything on the ground. And --

question: -- The roads are shut down, right?
answer: Most of this area doesn't even have roads.

question: begins climbing down to level ground so he can circle closer to where Travers is holding Hal -- before he can get far --
answer: smiles, looking macabre under the goggles, and opens fire --

question: is startled as the bullets impact inches over his head -- he jumps the last ten feet to the ground and is running even as he hits the ground -- more bullets hit where Gabe was a split second ago --
answer: chases Gabe, easily maneuvering through the trees --

question: runs too, trying to dodge Ryan's continuing fusillades -- Gabe knows this territory, but to him, it's still pitch dark -- he stumbles, and rams against trees --
answer: keeps coming up behind, closing the hap, Gabe's bright form just ahead --

question: comes out of the trees and finds he is on another part of the summit. All that's beneath him is is driven forward by a fresh burst of bullets -- he dives to the edge of the ice field and ducks behind a boulder -- the sole source of cover.
answer: almost casually emerges from the woods. He can see there is nowhere for Gabe to have gone -- except behind the boulder. He walks toward it as if he had all the time in the world.

question: fumbles in his backpack and pulls out something from the Douglas exhibit -- an ancient flare that looks like a can of sterno. Gabe pulls out his lighter and tries to light it -- it resists and looks like a dud, but finally it catches, and as it ignites Gabe heaves it over the boulder at Ryan --
answer: SCREAMS, putting one hand over the goggles, trying to rip them off --

question: bolts out from behind the boulder to rush him --
answer: instantly aware of what Gabe's doing, blindly shoots, fanning out in a semi-circle as he gets the goggles off --

question: We've got a fix on the plane, sir -- we're getting a reading on the flight recorder tracer --
answer: Any visual? Any radio contact?

question: Not yet --
answer: Get the copters ready. We take off in three minutes.

question: The winds are still too strong --
answer: Sorry to hear it. We're still going. The plane might be intact.

question: Sir --
answer: Shut up. That fifty million isn't coming out of my pension.

question: What are we going to do --
answer: You came up here to jump the spur -- This'd be a great time to do it.

question: But --
answer: Listen -- they don't know you're up here -- I'll draw their fire, you've got to make the jump and get help.

question: I don't -- I -- uh --
answer: Unless you want to do it the other way around?

question: unhappily walks through the carnage and past agents gathering up the plane, to a harried crash specialist from the FAA -- ROSS STUART -- who is organizing the debris. What can you confirm?
answer: Well, sir -- it crashed. That, I can confirm. We've been here just about one hour. These events take months to analyze. So if you'll excuse me --

question: No, I don't think I will. The reason the FAA pays you is to exercise your vast, amazing knowledge of these "events". So I expect you to come up with some stunning insights, something a slow-witted fuck like me hasn't already observed. One
answer: You'll be the first to know.

question: Bring it down here.
answer: Maggie --

question: Just do it, Frank.
answer: Maggie, this is dumb --

question: I've got something here.
answer: Let's have it.

question: There's an unconfirmed report of a distress call made from a plane that crashed.
answer: That's really, really interesting, but

question: This call was supposedly made from a plane that crash landed. After it landed.
answer: Sounds like they got it wrong. Next time you interrupt my work make sure it's something I can use.

question: Frank! Down here! Frank!
answer: Forget about it. He can't hear you. Tie these together. Tight.

question: -- Are you out of your mind --
answer: This is rope from the Gordon exhibit. The way guys climbed then, they'd tie on three at a time -- this rope'll take around nine hundred pounds.

question: Gabe -- this rope is sixty years old
answer: Yeah, they made it pretty good then. Each of these strands ought to hold about 300 pounds before snapping.

question: Ought to. About. Will it hold?
answer: Depends on how big a breakfast you had. You want to go first? Swing towards it -- and drop!

question: What the fuck --
answer: What -- who are --

question: Don't worry. I'm here to help.
answer: Glad to hear it.

question: Calling Rocky Mountain Rescue -- come in, Rocky Mountain Rescue -- over --
answer: Rocky Mountain Rescue One, over --

question: This is Ross Stuart, Federal Aviation Administration -- please identify -- over --
answer: Copy, FAA. This is Margaret Deighan, Rocky Mountain Rescue. Over --

question: We have an unconfirmed report of an air crash in your area, and a distress call on this frequency -- can you confirm -- over --
answer: Copy, FAA. Distress call came at approximately eleven hundred hours yesterday. I investigated -- the call turned out to be a false alarm. Over.

question: Please repeat, Rocky Mountain Rescue -- distress call was a false alarm? -- over --
answer: Repeat, distress call was a definite false alarm -- we've had several here. Somebody's sick idea of a joke. Do you require further assistance -- over --

question: I almost believed you myself.
answer: trembling with fury and grief, bent over Frank's body as the last trace of vapor -- his breath -- trails from his lips. He's gone. Hal gently closes the eyes of his friend. Goodbye, Frank.

question: Time for number three. Unless you want to have a longer conversation with him elsewhere.
answer: Fuck off. I think I'll wait here. You just murdered three of my friends. Sooner or later, whoever's chasing you is going to show up and return the favor, and I'd love to watch.

question: Are you okay?
answer: My ears are ringing -- but I'm all right. Gabe, what's going on?

question: This. That plane crash -- it's a half dozen guys who were smart enough to steal fifty million bucks, but dumb enough to drop it all over the range. They've got Hal as a bird dog -- and right now they're heading for the rest of it.
answer: Where?

question: It's close to the lake -- Hal's probably leading them on the slowest possible route down to it. I can get there first -- all I have to do is make it along the north wall to the Bitker ladder --
answer: "All?" Jesus, Gabe -- what do you expect to do then?

question: Something -- subtle.
answer: I'm going with you.

question: No way. You're climbing back down -- try to get to the station or find some help.
answer: I'm just as good a climber as you are -- and right now, I'm definitely in better shape.

question: And you're definitely not going -- Okay. Come on -- -- but the second you slow me down, I'm leaving -- -- I'm leaving you behind. Understood?
answer: Anything you say, Gabe.

question: One of the currency cases.
answer: We've tested the ash inside -- it's the right paper.

question: What about the men?
answer: It's -- hard to tell. But forensics says yes. All of them were in the plane.

question: Qualen. How far along are you?
answer: Not as far as we'd be with the helicopter.

question: We have less than half a tank of fuel, Eric -- if we burn it up treasure hunting we'll never get off this rock. Now -- how far away are you?
answer: It looks like two miles, but -- -- it'll take some time.

question: Time we have -- Walker's dead, Wright's an idiot. And our guide --
answer: What about him?

question: As soon as he becomes a convenience instead of a necessity -- kill him.
answer: Agreed.

question: Gabe? I'll go first.
answer: If I don't go first, I might not go at all.

question: tensely watches Gabe's crossing --
answer: pulls faster -- and reaches the other side. Gabe maintains his hand grip and swings his feet onto the ledge, leaning back against the wall to catch his breath. Think you can beat my time?

question: smiles -- this is more like the Gabe she remembers. She gets on the wire and starts across in a fast, easy rhythm.
answer: watches her, grinning. Admiration for Maggie is washing away bad memories of Susan. Shit -- she is in better shape. doesn't notice and shouts across at Maggie, now half way. Quit sandbagging it -- I haven't got all day -- drops low just as Maggie starts to fall and swings his arm out towards hers in one lightning-fast motion -- maintains his grip on Maggie's hand, but her weight nearly pulls him off the ledge -- Maggie drags him down, the window goes out of his chest when it collides with the ledge's bottom, but their grip holds. That -- tears it. You're not coming any further.

question: Gabe -- you're going to get yourself killed --
answer: Maybe. But I'm not getting you killed. Look, Maggie. I don't know what'll happen when I catch up with Hal -- but I've got to know one thing for sure -- that you're making it off this mountain. Alive.

question: Okay.
answer: Get on the trail and stay out of sight. I'll see you on the ground.

question: who is on a rise behind a rock, watches Qualen's futile pursuit from a distance, amused. Amused, until --
answer: You would have lived longer, if you weren't such a smartass. You telegraphed this kind of stunt with that joke snowman. Too bad for you we're not all gullible.

question: Good thing for Qualen you are.
answer: What do you mean?

question: When he comes back, he's going to shoot you and the other guy, grab the money, and take off with Travers.
answer: No sale. Say "night-night" --

question: He already blew up one of your pals in that crevice. And I've been in that copter. It goes a hell of a lot farther with two people than with four. Am I wrong? Give him a buzz.
answer: You've got my attention.

question: How much further?
answer: It's right over there. It's a storage locker for the rangers. Everything you need to get off the mountain is in there -- skiis, food -- I'll show you --

question: Don't move. Skiis, food -- and maybe guns too, right? Keep walking. Not too close.
answer: We'd make better time walking straight ahead. Qualen's not going to be hopping down the bunny trail too much longer.

question: Right. So I'd better have one less problem when he arrives.
answer: Don't fuck up. You still need me to show you a route off the mountain.

question: You've worn that one out, Walker -- -- I'll find my own way down.
answer: bellies ahead, flat on his stomach, testing the snow with the ice axe's staff -- only when he hits something solid with it does he get back up to his feet. But the sound of ice-crusted snow CRUNCHING above Gabe alerts him that --

question: bellies ahead, flat on his stomach, testing the snow with the ice axe's staff -- only when he hits something solid with it does he get back up to his feet. But the sound of ice-crusted snow CRUNCHING above Gabe alerts him that --
answer: has just hit the top of the slope and spotted him -- Qualen's gun BLAZES down --

question: is on the run, but it's that lead-footed, slow motion stuff that only happens in nightmares -- with every step, a foot breaks through the icy crust and sinks into two feet of snow -- Gabe stays just ahead of the barrage, making it into
answer: arrives where Gabe was and looks down the slope -- starts running down the slope -- he doesn't have speed, but he does have the machine gun -- he FIRES short bursts at --

question: Smiles and shakes his head. Too obvious. Gabe is hiding underneath the bridge, in the three foot deep network of steel supports. Qualen slows his pace, staring down through the thin, but visible cracks between the planks. You've come a long way to die. enjoying himself, slams a fresh clip into his machine gun. If you were smart, you'd have left your friend behind. I would have. There's no shame in staying alive. But you're not smart. And now you're going to die from an overdose of heroism. stops firing and kicks away the planks, which are a tangle of toothpicks at this point -- Qualen bends down -- Stalemate, isn't it?
answer: Not any more.

question: Far more intimidating when it's loaded.
answer: quickly reacts, jumping onto another bed-sized chunk of ice floating by, landing on his stomach and braking himself by digging his crampons in -- just as --

question: realizing what deep shit he's in, looks for another chunk of ice to make the same move -- to sees one just out of reach. Qualen pulls the ice axe out of the raft's center to drag the other chunk closer in -- -- as he does, the entire raft disintegrates under him -- Qualen plunges into the water, and tries to maintain a slippery grip on what ice is left --
answer: struggles to his feet and looks down, wincing -- has no time to celebrate -- the chunk of ice he's on leaves him moments from the same fate. One more time around, and it's down the drain. Gabe takes a deep breath. No choice. He leaps -- lands on an ice raft floating towards the bridge. No choice -- Gabe lunges off the ice raft and reaches for one of the bridge supports -- his hand catches -- but it's slippery and he's weakened -- Gabe slides off, but --

question: struggles to his feet and looks down, wincing -- has no time to celebrate -- the chunk of ice he's on leaves him moments from the same fate. One more time around, and it's down the drain. Gabe takes a deep breath. No choice. He leaps -- lands on an ice raft floating towards the bridge. No choice -- Gabe lunges off the ice raft and reaches for one of the bridge supports -- his hand catches -- but it's slippery and he's weakened -- Gabe slides off, but --
answer: pulls Gabe the rest of the way onto the bridge. Gabe's surprise gives way to a grin almost as big as Hal's. Nice outfit. I know you never liked the orange, but

question: Didn't care for the Smokey The Bear hats, either. That's why I quit. You all right?
answer: I feel better than you look. I can live with that.

question: Hardly seems worth zipping, huh? Frank?
answer: It's not over, Gabe. Travers took the helicopter.

question: I've got the money. Fly to the lake. And if you touch her --
answer: Now what?

question: I have no fucking idea. Empty.
answer: Not for long.

question: Stay over there --
answer: Look -- let me --

question: -- what, throw snowballs at him? Just -- whatever happens -- get Maggie out of here.
answer: Count on it. And Gabe? Thanks for tagging along.

question: Remember that bet you made? About whether I could find the money for you or not? You won.
answer: I'll kill her --

question: You do, and the spring thaw's going to be worth thirty million bucks. No rush. I'm sure you've got lots of time.
answer: All right. Drop the gun first.

question: When she's safe on the ground.
answer: Get out.

question: Run! Run! Now come and get it. My arm's getting tired. Don't you want to count it?
answer: stares down, incredulous -- as he does --

question: with its skids skipping just over the snow overtakes --
answer: as he throws himself flat into the snow -- the front of the skid misses Gabe by inches as it blasts over him --

question: moves out over the precipice edge -- Travers banks it wide to circle back around for another run --
answer: gets back up as the helicopter swings back behind him --

question: has circled back around, stopping at a hover far back in the clearing -- Travers intends to not just run Gabe over, but to run him off the edge as well --
answer: lumbers as fast as he can towards the edge --

question: as he runs toward the mountain's edge -- it's just a couple of feet ahead, but the copter is a couple of feet behind --
answer: skid meant to impale Gabe catches the top two rungs of the cable ladder -- still strains against the cable ladder but the engine goes dead -- the rotor blades slow --

question: is shaken off by the massive impact -- he falls -- -- landing on the helicopter, half in and half out of the cockpit! As Gabe scrambles for a solid hold --
answer: slips, now hanging from just a single rung -- -- and the impact of the slip makes Travers drop the gun -- it falls out the open passenger door. Travers scrambles up through the cabin to go after -- -- Gabe, who is trying to get off the helicopter and onto a solid part of the ladder before the whole thing goes down -- Gabe jumps for the wall as Travers scrambles behind him and --
